revisions.*: Because "rvslots" was not specified, a legacy format has been used for the output. This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used.

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Taxobox | image = Cviscosa wiki.jpg | image_caption = At [[Durmitor|Durmitor National Park]], [[Montenegro]] | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Dacrymycetes]] | ordo = [[Dacrymycetales]] | familia = [[Dacrymycetaceae]] | genus = ''[[Calocera]]'' | species = '''''C. viscosa''''' | binomial = ''Calocera viscosa'' | binomial_authority = ([[Christiaan Hendrik Persoon|Pers.]]) [[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]] (1827).
According to MicoBank the correct binomial name is ''Clavaria viscosa'' Pers (1794)http://www.mycobank.org/BioloMICS.aspx?Link=T&TableKey=14682616000000067&Rec=77924&Fields=All Mycobank, retrieved 16 August 2012 }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Calocera viscosa'' | hymeniumType=smooth | whichGills = no | capShape = no | stipeCharacter=bare | ecologicalType= saprotrophic | sporePrintColor=white | howEdible=unpalatable}} {{commons category}} '''''Calocera viscosa''''', commonly known as the '''yellow stagshorn''', is a jelly fungus, a member of the [[Dacrymycetales]], an order of fungi characterized by their unique "tuning fork" [[basidia]]. It has bright orange, yellow or occasionally white branching [[basidiocarp]]s, which are somewhat gelatinous in texture and slimy to the touch (hence the specific name). It is relatively large for a jelly fungus, and can reach up to ten centimetres in height.http://www.first-nature.com/fungi/calocera-viscosa.php First Nature, retrieved 16 August 2012 It is widespread and common, and its bright colour makes it stand out in its habitat. It grows on decaying [[conifer]] wood, typically stumps and roots, although this may not be obvious if the wood is covered in leaf litter. It fruits throughout the year, but is most commonly seen in autumn. It is not poisonous, but its tough gelatinous texture and nondescript taste and odour make it unattractive as a food. Its striking colour has led to it being used as a garnish on occasion, however.http://www.mushroomdiary.co.uk/2011/10/yellow-stagshorn-fungus/ Mushroom Diary, retrieved 16 August 2012 ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q256970}} [[Category:Dacrymycetes]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1827]] {{Basidiomycota-stub}}
